what: Convert Between Standardised Test Scores. — convert_standard
title: Convert Between Standardised Test Scores. — convert_standard
text: function converts standardised scores various metrics commonly used psychological educational testing. conversion supports several score types including Z scores, T scores, index scores, scaled scores, sten scores, stanine scores, SAT scores, percentile ranks.

title: Convert Between Standardised Test Scores. — convert_standard
code: convert_standard(   score,   metric = "z",   metric.new = "index",   mean.new = NULL,   sd.new = NULL,   dp = 2 )

title: Convert Between Standardised Test Scores. — convert_standard
text: score Numeric value (vector) containing standardised scores converted. metric Character string specifying metric input scores. ("z", "t", "index", "scaled", "sten", "stanine", "sat", "percentile"). Default "z". metric.new Character string specifying metric convert input scores . Choose "z", "t", "index", "scaled", "sten", "stanine", "sat", "percentile". Default "z". mean.new Optional numeric value specifying mean new metric. provided, takes precedence metric.new. sd.new Optional numeric value specifying standard deviation new metric. provided, takes precedence metric.new. dp Integer specifying number decimal places round converted scores . Default 2.

title: Convert Between Standardised Test Scores. — convert_standard
text: numeric value vector converted scores.

title: Convert Between Standardised Test Scores. — convert_standard
text: function flexible, allowing custom mean standard deviation inputs new metric, making suitable wide range standardised testing applications. conversion process uses linear transformation based properties normal distribution. Specifically, conversion performed using formula (described Crawford, 2004): $$X_{\text{new}} = \frac{\sigma_{\text{new}}}{\sigma_{\text{old}}} \times (X_{\text{old}} - \bar{X}_{\text{old}}) + \bar{X}_{\text{new}}$$ : \(X_{\text{new}}\) converted score, \(X_{\text{old}}\) original score, \(\bar{X}_{\text{old}}\) \(\sigma_{\text{old}}\) mean standard deviation original metric. \(\bar{X}_{\text{new}}\) \(\sigma_{\text{new}}\) mean standard deviation new metric. table summarizing default mean standard deviation metric:

title: Convert Between Standardised Test Scores. — convert_standard
text: Ensure metric metric.new correctly specified, incorrect metrics may lead inappropriate score conversions. function assumes input scores correctly standardised according specified input metric.

title: Convert Between Standardised Test Scores. — convert_standard
text: Crawford, J. R. (2013). Quantitative aspects neuropsychological assessment. L. H. Goldstein & J. E. McNeil (Eds.), Clinical neuropsychology: practical guide assessment management clinicians (2nd ed., pp. 97-121). Wiley-Blackwell.

title: Convert Between Standardised Test Scores. — convert_standard
code: # Convert a Z score to a T score convert_standard(score = 2, metric = "z", metric.new = "t", dp = 2) #> [1] 70  # Convert a Z score to a Percentile Rank convert_standard(score = 2, metric = "z", metric.new = "percentile", dp = 2) #> [1] 97.72  # Convert a Z score to a custom metric with mean 60 and standard deviation 15 convert_standard(score = 2, metric = "z", mean.new = 60, sd.new = 15, dp = 2) #> [1] 90  # Convert multiple scores from T scores to scaled scores convert_standard(score = c(50, 55, 60), metric = "t", metric.new = "scaled", dp = 2) #> [1] 10.0 11.5 13.0

what: Convert Z Score to Alternative Standardized Score. — convert_z
title: Convert Z Score to Alternative Standardized Score. — convert_z
text: function takes Z score converts one number alternative derived scores (e.g., T score, index score, scaled score, sten score, stanine score, SAT score, percentile).

title: Convert Z Score to Alternative Standardized Score. — convert_z
code: convert_z(z, metric = "index", mean.new = NULL, sd.new = NULL, dp = 2)

title: Convert Z Score to Alternative Standardized Score. — convert_z
text: z Numeric input (vector) specifying Z score conversion. metric Character string specifying metric convert Z scores . Choose "z", "t", "index", "scaled", "sten", "stanine", "sat", "percentile". Default "z". mean.new Optional numeric value specifying mean new metric. provided, takes precedence metric. sd.new Optional numeric value specifying standard deviation new metric. provided, takes precedence metric. dp Integer specifying number decimal places round converted scores . Default 2.

title: Convert Z Score to Alternative Standardized Score. — convert_z
text: numeric value vector converted scores. numeric value

title: Convert Z Score to Alternative Standardized Score. — convert_z
text: function flexible, allowing custom mean standard deviation inputs new metric, making suitable wide range standardised testing applications. conversion process uses linear transformation based properties normal distribution. Specifically, conversion performed using formula (described Crawford, 2004): $$ X_{\text{new}} = \frac{\sigma_{\text{new}}}{\sigma_{\text{old}}} \times (X_{\text{old}} - \bar{X}_{\text{old}}) + \bar{X}_{\text{new}} $$ : \(X_{\text{new}}\) converted score, \(X_{\text{old}}\) original score, \(\bar{X}_{\text{old}}\) \(\sigma_{\text{old}}\) mean standard deviation original metric. \(\bar{X}_{\text{new}}\) \(\sigma_{\text{new}}\) mean standard deviation new metric. table summarizing default mean standard deviation metric:

title: Convert Z Score to Alternative Standardized Score. — convert_z
code: convert_z(z = 2, metric = "index") #> [1] 130 convert_z(z = 0.32, metric = "sten") #> [1] 6.14 convert_z(z = 1, metric = "percentile") #> [1] 84.13 convert_z(z = 1, mean.new = 60, sd.new = 15) #> [1] 75

what: Bayesian Dissociation Single Case Analysis — dissociation_bayes_single
title: Bayesian Dissociation Single Case Analysis — dissociation_bayes_single
text: function performs Bayesian single-case analysis assess abnormality given score compared control group. generates simulated distributions scores based control group's mean, standard deviation, sample size, provides Bayesian credible intervals, p-values, abnormality percentages.

title: Bayesian Dissociation Single Case Analysis — dissociation_bayes_single
code: dissociation_bayes_single(   score,   ctrl.mean,   ctrl.sd,   ctrl.n,   conf.level = 0.95,   direction = "lower",   dp = 4,   sims = 10000,   treshold = 0.1 )

title: Bayesian Dissociation Single Case Analysis — dissociation_bayes_single
text: score Numeric value representing score single case. ctrl.mean Numeric value representing mean control group. ctrl.sd Numeric value representing standard deviation control group. ctrl.n Integer value representing sample size control group. conf.level Numeric value specifying confidence level credible interval. Default 0.95. direction Character string indicating direction test, either "lower" "higher". Default "lower". dp Integer specifying number decimal places round results. Default 4. sims Integer specifying number simulations perform. Default 10000. treshold Numeric value abnormality threshold. Default 0.1.

title: Bayesian Dissociation Single Case Analysis — dissociation_bayes_single
text: list containing: score original score provided. ctrl.mean mean control group. ctrl.sd standard deviation control group. ctrl.n sample size control group. conf.level confidence level used credible interval. sims number simulations performed. treshold abnormality threshold used. direction direction test ("lower" "higher"). dp number decimal places used rounding. df degrees freedom control group (n-1). ctrl.var variance control group. z calculated z-score single case. z.ci.lb lower bound Bayesian credible interval z-score. z.ci.ub upper bound Bayesian credible interval z-score. percentile percentile rank score control group. p p-value based direction test. p.two.tailed two-tailed p-value. abn percentage abnormality. abn.ci.lb lower bound Bayesian credible interval abnormality percentage. abn.ci.ub upper bound Bayesian credible interval abnormality percentage.

title: Bayesian Dissociation Single Case Analysis — dissociation_bayes_single
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ result <- dissociation_bayes_single(   score = 90,   ctrl.mean = 100,   ctrl.sd = 15,   ctrl.n = 30,   conf.level = 0.95,   direction = "lower",   dp = 4,   sims = 10000,   treshold = 0.1 ) print(result) } # }

what: Calculate abnormality of two test scores with confidence intervals using the modified t-test. — dissociation_double
title: Calculate abnormality of two test scores with confidence intervals using the modified t-test. — dissociation_double
text: Calculate abnormality two test scores confidence intervals using modified t-test.

title: Calculate abnormality of two test scores with confidence intervals using the modified t-test. — dissociation_double
code: dissociation_double(   ctrl.mean.x,   ctrl.sd.x,   ctrl.mean.y,   ctrl.sd.y,   ctrl.r.xy,   ctrl.n,   score.x,   score.y,   conf.level = 0.95,   direction = "lower",   dp = 4,   test.names = c("X", "Y") )

title: Calculate abnormality of two test scores with confidence intervals using the modified t-test. — dissociation_double
text: ctrl.mean.x Mean control group first test. ctrl.sd.x Standard deviation control group first test. ctrl.mean.y Mean control group second test. ctrl.sd.y Standard deviation control group second test. ctrl.r.xy Correlation two tests control group. ctrl.n Size control group. score.x Test score individual first test. score.y Test score individual second test. conf.level Confidence level interval (default 0.05). direction Direction test, either "lower" "higher" (default "lower"). dp Number decimal places rounding results (default 2). test.names vector two strings representing names tests (default c("X", "Y")).

title: Calculate abnormality of two test scores with confidence intervals using the modified t-test. — dissociation_double
text: list containing z-scores tests, control group means standard deviations, correlation tests, control group size, scores tests, confidence level, direction test, t-value, p-value, two-tailed p-value, zdcc, zdcc confidence interval lower bound, zdcc confidence interval upper bound, abnormality percentage, abnormality confidence interval lower bound, abnormality confidence interval upper bound.

title: Calculate abnormality of two test scores with confidence intervals using the modified t-test. — dissociation_double
code: dissociation_double(100, 15, 110, 10, 0.5, 30, 130, 120, test.names = c("Test A", "Test B")) #> Frequentist Double Dissociation #>  #> Frequentist point estimate and confidence limits on the abnormality of test score differences within a single case. #>  #> INPUTS: #>  #> Test      Mean   SD  Sample size   r      Case score #> -------  -----  ---  ------------  ----  ----------- #> Test A     100   15  30            0.5           130 #> Test B     110   10                              120 #>  #> OUTPUTS: #>  #> Variable                                        Value       95% Confidence Interval  #> ----------------------------------------------  ----------  ------------------------ #> Effect size (z) for test Test A                 2.000                                #> Effect size (z) for test Test B                 1.000                                #> Effect size (z-dcc) between Test A and Test B   1.000       0.5541 to 1.4343         #> t value                                         0.984                                #> One-tailed p-value                              0.8334                               #> Two-tailed p-value                              0.3333                               #> Abnormality                                     83.3373 %   71.0259 % to 92.4261 %   #>  #> Based on: Crawford, Garthwaite & Howell (1998).

what: Assessing For a Frequentist Single Dissociation Between a Test Score and a Control Sample. — dissociation_single
title: Assessing For a Frequentist Single Dissociation Between a Test Score and a Control Sample. — dissociation_single
text: Assess dissociation single test score control sample using modified t-test estimate abnormality test score, including confidence intervals.

title: Assessing For a Frequentist Single Dissociation Between a Test Score and a Control Sample. — dissociation_single
code: dissociation_single(   score,   ctrl.mean,   ctrl.sd,   ctrl.n,   conf.level = 0.95,   direction = "lower",   dp = 2 )

title: Assessing For a Frequentist Single Dissociation Between a Test Score and a Control Sample. — dissociation_single
text: score Test score individual case. ctrl.mean Mean control group. ctrl.sd Standard deviation control group. ctrl.n Size control group. conf.level Confidence level (default 0.95 95%). direction Direction test, either "lower" "higher" (default "lower"). dp Number decimal places rounding results (default 2).

title: Assessing For a Frequentist Single Dissociation Between a Test Score and a Control Sample. — dissociation_single
text: list statistical input, parameters, results. Key outputs include: t value: t-value calculated test. p value: p-value test, indicating statistical significance. effect-size (zcc): z-score (effect-size) corrected control group. abnormality: percentage population expected score extreme score.

title: Assessing For a Frequentist Single Dissociation Between a Test Score and a Control Sample. — dissociation_single
text: Perform dissociation single test score control sample using modified paired samples t-test approach Crawford et al. (1998). Unlike earlier (e.g. Payne & Jones) method treats data normative sample statistics population parameters. result provided t score associated p value. approach helps reconcile problem associated small control samples. addition determining whether difference exists also important understand magnitude difference. Therefore, often recommended effect sizes provided alongside p-values estimate size observed effect. effect, Crawford et al. (1998) provide method deriving effect-size single-case studies using case-controls design, single patient's cognitive performance compared matched control group. modified z-score (z-cc) provided point interval estimates. Neuropsychologists often need determine abnormal patient's test score . context, abnormality can easily estimated multiplying t-value modified t-test 100, suggested Crawford Howell (1998). estimate quantifies percentage population expected exhibit extreme score. can calculated specific direction (.e., higher lower score), alternatively, abnormality 'either' direction can determined dividing percentage two. Methods also provided calculate confidence limits estimate abnormality (Crawford & Garthwaite, 2002) included.

title: Assessing For a Frequentist Single Dissociation Between a Test Score and a Control Sample. — dissociation_single
text: Crawford, J.R., & Garthwaite, P.H. (2002). Investigation single case neuropsychology: confidence limits abnormality test scores test score differences. Neuropsychologia, 40(2002), 1196–1208. Crawford, J.R., Howell, D.C., & Garthwaite, P.H. (1998). Payne Jones Revisited: Estimating Abnormality Test Score Differences Using Modified Paired Samples t Test. Journal Clinical Experimental Neuropsychology, 20(6), 898-905. Crawford, J.R., & Howell, D.C. (1998). Comparing individual’s test score norms derived small samples. Clinical Neuropsychologist, 12(4), 482-486. Crawford, J.R., Garthwaite, P.H., & Porter, S. (2010). Point interval estimates effect sizes case-controls design neuropsychology: Rationale, methods, implementations, proposed reporting standards. Cognitive Neuropsychology, 27(3), 245-260. Payne, R. W., & Jones, G. (1957). Statistics investigation individual cases. Journal Clinical Psychology, 13, 115-121.

title: Assessing For a Frequentist Single Dissociation Between a Test Score and a Control Sample. — dissociation_single
code: # Example 1: Basic usage result <- dissociation_single(   score = 75,   ctrl.mean = 70,   ctrl.sd = 10,   ctrl.n = 30 ) print(result) #> Frequentist Single Dissociation Between a Test Score and a Control Sample. #>  #> INPUTS: #>  #> Variable             Value #> ------------------  ------ #> Sample mean             70 #> Sample SD               10 #> Sample size             30 #> Case's test score       75 #>  #> OUTPUTS: #>  #> Variable                   Value     95% Confidence Interval  #> -------------------------  --------  ------------------------ #> t value                    0.49                               #> p-val (lower)              0.69                               #> p-val (either direction)   0.63                               #> Effect size (Z-CC)         0.50      0.12 to 0.88             #> Abnormality                68.67 %   54.62  % to 80.96 %      #>  #> see documentation for further information on computation.  # Example 2: With a higher direction and different confidence level result <- dissociation_single(   score = 85,   ctrl.mean = 70,   ctrl.sd = 10,   ctrl.n = 30,   direction = "higher",   conf.level = 0.99 ) print(result) #> Frequentist Single Dissociation Between a Test Score and a Control Sample. #>  #> INPUTS: #>  #> Variable             Value #> ------------------  ------ #> Sample mean             70 #> Sample SD               10 #> Sample size             30 #> Case's test score       85 #>  #> OUTPUTS: #>  #> Variable                   Value    99% Confidence Interval  #> -------------------------  -------  ------------------------ #> t value                    1.48                              #> p-val (higher)             0.08                              #> p-val (either direction)   0.15                              #> Effect size (Z-CC)         1.50     0.97 to 2.02             #> Abnormality                7.54 %   16.63  % to 2.18 %       #>  #> see documentation for further information on computation.  # Example 3: Using more decimal places result <- dissociation_single(   score = 85,   ctrl.mean = 70,   ctrl.sd = 10,   ctrl.n = 30,   dp = 4 ) print(result) #> Frequentist Single Dissociation Between a Test Score and a Control Sample. #>  #> INPUTS: #>  #> Variable             Value #> ------------------  ------ #> Sample mean             70 #> Sample SD               10 #> Sample size             30 #> Case's test score       85 #>  #> OUTPUTS: #>  #> Variable                   Value       95% Confidence Interval  #> -------------------------  ----------  ------------------------ #> t value                    1.4756                               #> p-val (lower)              0.9246                               #> p-val (either direction)   0.1508                               #> Effect size (Z-CC)         1.5000      0.9688 to 2.0188         #> Abnormality                92.4587 %   83.3675  % to 97.8248 %  #>  #> see documentation for further information on computation.

title: Generate Composite Scores — generate_composite
text: function calculates composite scores based subtest correlations inter-correlations.

title: Generate Composite Scores — generate_composite
code: generate_composite(   r,   r.between,   mean = 10,   sd = 3,   comp.mean = 100,   comp.sd = 15,   dp = 4 )

title: Generate Composite Scores — generate_composite
text: r numeric vector correlations included tests. r.numeric vector inter-correlations included tests. mean numeric value specifying mean included tests. Default 10. sd numeric value specifying standard deviation included tests. Default 3. comp.mean numeric value specifying mean composite score. Default 100. comp.sd numeric value specifying standard deviation composite score. Default 15. dp integer specifying number decimal places rounding results. Default 4.

title: Generate Composite Scores — generate_composite
text: list class 'gen_comp' containing: k Number subtests. r Vector correlations included tests. r.Vector inter-correlations included tests. composite_r Composite correlation. original_mean Original mean composite score. original_sd Original standard deviation composite score. original_sem Original standard error measurement. original_semt Original standard error mean transformed. transformed.mean Transformed mean composite score. transformed.sd Transformed standard deviation composite score. transformed.sem Transformed standard error measurement. transformed.semt Transformed standard error mean transformed.

title: Generate Composite Scores — generate_composite
code: result <- generate_composite(r = c(.87, .94, .94),                              r.between = c(0.74, 0.64, 0.73),                              dp = 3) print(result) #> Generate Composite Score #>  #> INPUTS: #>  #>  #> Inputs                     Value             #> -------------------------  ----------------- #> Number of tests included   3                 #> r for included tests       0.87, 0.94, 0.94  #> r between included tests   0.74, 0.64, 0.73  #>  #> OUTPUTS: #>  #>  #> Outputs       Original   Transformed  #> ------------  ---------  ------------ #> Composite r   0.9650                  #> Mean          30.0000    100.0000     #> SD            7.4820     15.0000      #> SEM           1.3920     2.7910       #> SEMt (true)   1.3440     2.6950

what: Generate a descriptor for a derived score. — generate_descriptor
title: Generate a descriptor for a derived score. — generate_descriptor
text: function converts index scores descriptive labels based predefined threshold values various descriptor systems AAN, WISC, WAIS, NEPSY, Q.Simple, Groth-Marnat, Heaton.

title: Generate a descriptor for a derived score. — generate_descriptor
code: generate_descriptor(score, metric = "index", system = "aan")

title: Generate a descriptor for a derived score. — generate_descriptor
text: score Numeric value (vector) containing index scores converted descriptors. metric Character string specifying metric input scores. ("z", "t", "index", "scaled", "sten", "stanine", "sat"). Default "index". system Character string specifying descriptor system use. Default "aan".

title: Generate a descriptor for a derived score. — generate_descriptor
text: character vector containing descriptors corresponding input index scores.

title: Generate a descriptor for a derived score. — generate_descriptor
text: function uses predefined threshold values descriptor labels descriptor system convert index scores descriptive categories. allows customization descriptor system rounding input scores.

title: Generate a descriptor for a derived score. — generate_descriptor
code: # Convert index scores to descriptors using the AAN descriptor system generate_descriptor(score = c(85, 105, 120), metric = "index", system = "aan") #> [1] "Low Average"   "Average"       "Above Average"  # Convert index scores to descriptors using the NEPSY descriptor system generate_descriptor(score = c(75, 95, 110), metric = "index", system = "nepsy") #> [1] "Borderline"           "At Expected Level"    "Above Expected Level"

what: Calculate score deviances and significance — generate_discreps_from_mean
title: Calculate score deviances and significance — generate_discreps_from_mean
text: function calculates mean deviances test scores mean, evaluates significance, computes various related statistics.

title: Calculate score deviances and significance — generate_discreps_from_mean
code: generate_discreps_from_mean(   x,   R = NULL,   sem,   sd = 15,   dp = 2,   names = NULL,   conf.level = 0.9,   threshold = -1.645,   apply_bonferroni = FALSE,   alpha = 0.05 )

title: Calculate score deviances and significance — generate_discreps_from_mean
text: x numeric vector test scores. R numeric matrix representing correlation matrix. provided, correlation-based calculations skipped. sem numeric vector standard error measurement (SEM) values. sd Standard deviation test scores. Default 15. dp Number decimal places rounding results. Default 2. names Optional character vector names test scores. provided, default names used. conf.level Confidence level confidence intervals. Default 0.90. threshold Threshold abnormality detection. Default -1.645. apply_bonferroni Logical, whether apply Bonferroni correction. Default FALSE. alpha Significance level used Bonferroni correction. Default 0.05.

title: Calculate score deviances and significance — generate_discreps_from_mean
text: list containing various statistics results.

title: Calculate score deviances and significance — generate_discreps_from_mean
code: sem <- c(3.000000, 3.354102, 3.674235, 4.743416) scores <- c(118, 107, 77, 68) R <- matrix(c(1.00, 0.61, 0.64, 0.45,               0.61, 1.00, 0.62, 0.52,               0.64, 0.62, 1.00, 0.51,               0.45, 0.52, 0.51, 1.00), nrow = 4, byrow = TRUE) names <- c("Verbal Comprehension", "Perceptual Reasoning",            "Working Memory", "Processing Speed") generate_discreps_from_mean(scores, R = R, sem = sem, conf.level = 0.95, names = names) #> ABNORMALITY of Index score deviations from the case's mean Index score: #> Case's mean Index score: 92.5 #>  #>  Test    Discrep        95 % CI         p-val 2t    p-val 1t    Abnormal 2d    Abnormal 1d  #> ------  ---------  ------------------  ----------  ----------  -------------  ------------- #>   VC      25.5       19.95 to 31.05      <1e-04      <1e-04        0.26           0.13      #>   PR      14.5       8.57 to 20.43       <1e-04      <1e-04        7.45           3.72      #>   WM      -15.5     -21.78 to -9.22      <1e-04      <1e-04        5.24           2.62      #>   PS      -24.5     -32.03 to -16.97     <1e-04      <1e-04        1.26           0.63      #>  #> NUMBER of case's deviation scores that meet criterion for abnormality = 2 #>  #> PERCENTAGE of normal population expected to exhibit this number or more of abnormally low scores = 4.302%

what: Calculate the percentile of a value in a dataset — generate_percentile
title: Calculate the percentile of a value in a dataset — generate_percentile
text: function calculates percentile given value dataset using one three methods: "", "b", "c".

title: Calculate the percentile of a value in a dataset — generate_percentile
code: generate_percentile(data, x, method = "c")

title: Calculate the percentile of a value in a dataset — generate_percentile
text: data numeric vector representing dataset. x value calculate percentile. method method use calculating percentile. Options "", "b", "c". Defaults "c".

title: Calculate the percentile of a value in a dataset — generate_percentile
text: percentile value dataset.

title: Calculate the percentile of a value in a dataset — generate_percentile
code: data <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5) generate_percentile(data, 3, method = "c") #> [1] 50

title: Calculate Percentile Norms — generate_percentile_norms
text: function calculates percentile norms given dataset.

title: Calculate Percentile Norms — generate_percentile_norms
code: generate_percentile_norms(dat, method = "all", range = NULL)

title: Calculate Percentile Norms — generate_percentile_norms
text: dat numeric vector representing dataset percentile norms calculated. method character string specifying method calculating percentiles: "" method , "b" method b, "c" method c, "" methods. Default "". range optional numeric vector specifying range values calculate percentiles, range specified sequence (e.g., (1:12)). Default range minimum maximum value dataset.

title: Calculate Percentile Norms — generate_percentile_norms
text: data frame containing following columns: raw raw values percentiles calculated. count count occurrences raw value dataset. definition_a percentile values calculated using method "". definition_b percentile values calculated using method "b". definition_c percentile values calculated using method "c".

title: Calculate Percentile Norms — generate_percentile_norms
code: # Generate example data set.seed(123) data <- rnorm(100)  # Calculate percentile norms using all methods generate_percentile_norms(data, method = "all") #>          raw count definition_a definition_b definition_c #> 1 -2.3091689     1            0            1          0.5 #> 2 -1.3091689     0            4            4          4.0 #> 3 -0.3091689     0           34           34         34.0 #> 4  0.6908311     0           75           75         75.0 #> 5  1.6908311     0           95           95         95.0  # Calculate percentile norms using a specific method generate_percentile_norms(data, method = "c") #>          raw count definition_c #> 1 -2.3091689     1          0.5 #> 2 -1.3091689     0          4.0 #> 3 -0.3091689     0         34.0 #> 4  0.6908311     0         75.0 #> 5  1.6908311     0         95.0  # re-create Crawford (2009) table crawford_2009 <- c(rep(0:12, c(0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 2, 4, 4, 14, 16, 20, 30, 10))) generate_percentile_norms(crawford_2009) #>   raw count definition_a definition_b definition_c #> 1   5     2            0            2            1 #> 2   6     4            2            6            4 #> 3   7     4            6           10            8 #> 4   8    14           10           24           17 #> 5   9    16           24           40           32 #> 6  10    20           40           60           50 #> 7  11    30           60           90           75 #> 8  12    10           90          100           95

what: Calculate the percentiles of a vector of values — generate_percentile_vector
title: Calculate the percentiles of a vector of values — generate_percentile_vector

code: generate_percentile_vector(data, method = "c")

title: Calculate the percentiles of a vector of values — generate_percentile_vector
text: data numeric vector representing dataset. method method use calculating percentiles. Options "", "b", "c". Defaults "c".

title: Calculate the percentiles of a vector of values — generate_percentile_vector
text: numeric vector containing percentiles input data.

title: Calculate the percentiles of a vector of values — generate_percentile_vector
code: data <- c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5) generate_percentile_vector(data, method = "c") #> [1] 10 30 50 70 90

title: Calculate Prevalence — generate_prevalence
text: function calculates prevalence based given z-score.

title: Calculate Prevalence — generate_prevalence
code: generate_prevalence(z, method = "proportion", two.tailed = FALSE, dp = 5)

title: Calculate Prevalence — generate_prevalence
text: z numeric value representing z-score. method character string specifying method calculate prevalence. must one "percentage", "proportion", "ratio" (default: "ratio"). two.tailed Logical indicating whether consider tails distribution calculating prevalence (default: FALSE). dp Integer specifying number decimal places result (default: 5).

title: Calculate Prevalence — generate_prevalence
text: prevalence calculated based specified method.

title: Calculate Prevalence — generate_prevalence
code: generate_prevalence(z = -1, method = "proportion", two.tailed = TRUE, dp = 5) #> [1] 0.31731 generate_prevalence(z = -1, method = "proportion", two.tailed = FALSE, dp = 5) #> [1] 0.15866

what: Generate Regression Norms for a Single Variable — generate_regression_norms_single_var
title: Generate Regression Norms for a Single Variable — generate_regression_norms_single_var
text: function generates regression norms performs significance testing individual's score predictor variable. calculates regression equation, standard errors, significance levels based summary statistics control sample.

title: Generate Regression Norms for a Single Variable — generate_regression_norms_single_var
code: generate_regression_norms_single_var(   ctrl.x.mean,   ctrl.x.sd,   ctrl.y.mean,   ctrl.y.sd,   r,   n,   x,   y,   conf.level = 0.05,   direction = "lower",   dp = 4,   x.name = "X",   y.name = "Y" )

title: Generate Regression Norms for a Single Variable — generate_regression_norms_single_var
text: ctrl.x.mean Mean predictor variable control sample. ctrl.x.sd Standard deviation predictor variable control sample. ctrl.y.mean Mean criterion variable control sample. ctrl.y.sd Standard deviation criterion variable control sample. r Correlation coefficient predictor criterion variables control sample. n Sample size control group. x Score individual predictor variable. y Obtained score individual criterion variable. conf.level Confidence level significance test. Default 0.05. direction Direction significance test. Options "lower" "upper". Default "lower". dp Number decimal places. x.name Name predictor variable. Default "X". y.name Name criterion variable. Default "Y".

title: Generate Regression Norms for a Single Variable — generate_regression_norms_single_var
text: list containing calculated values results.

title: Generate Regression Norms for a Single Variable — generate_regression_norms_single_var
code: generate_regression_norms_single_var(   ctrl.x.mean = 63.8,   ctrl.x.sd = 8.42,   ctrl.y.mean = 41.3,   ctrl.y.sd = 13.2,   r = -0.58,   n = 160,   x = 26,   y = 41,   x.name = "Predictor",   y.name = "Criterion" ) #> Neuropsychological Regression Norms Single Case Analysis #>  #> Regression norms and significance testing for an individual case based on the control sample. #>  #> INPUTS: #>  #> Variable                 Mean      SD   Case's Score  n     r        t1 Score #> ----------------------  -----  ------  -------------  ----  ------  --------- #> Predictor (Predictor)    63.8    8.42             26  160   -0.58          26 #> Criterion (Criterion)    41.3   13.20             41                       41 #>  #> OUTPUTS: #>  #> Outputs                                     Value                         #> ------------------------------------------  ----------------------------- #> Regression equation (Predicted Y)           99.311 + -0.9093 * Predictor  #> Standard error of estimate                  10.7869                       #> Case's PREDICTED score                      75.6702                       #> Discrepancy (Observed - Predicted)          -34.6702                      #> Effect size (Z-OP)                          -3.2243                       #> t value                                     -3.0196                       #> One-tailed p-value                          0.0015                        #> Two-tailed p-value                          0.0030                        #> Estimated % with more extreme discrepancy   0.1476 %                      #>  #> Based on: Crawford, Garthwaite, & Porter (2010), Crawford & Garthwaite (2002), and Crawford & Howell (1998).

title: Plot Bell Curve — plot_bell_curve
text: Plot Bell Curve

title: Plot Bell Curve — plot_bell_curve
code: plot_bell_curve(   input,   metric = "z",   score.label.text = "test",   axis.label.metric = metric,   descriptors = TRUE )

title: Plot Bell Curve — plot_bell_curve
text: input numeric value (vector numbers) representing score interest. metric character string specifying metric input score: "percentile", "t", "index", "scaled", "z" (default). score.label.text character string (vector character strings) label text input score(s). axis.label.metric character string specifying preferred metric label x-axis labels: "percentile", "t", "index", "scaled", "z" (default). descriptors logical indicating whether include AAN descriptor labels (default TRUE).

title: Plot Bell Curve — plot_bell_curve
text: ggplot2 object.

title: Plot Bell Curve — plot_bell_curve
code: plot_bell_curve(input = 2, score.label.text = "Test Score", axis.label.metric = "z")

title: Plot a Forest Plot — plot_forest
text: Creates forest plot visualizing scores confidence intervals across different tests groups. plot includes optional shading descriptors provide additional context.

title: Plot a Forest Plot — plot_forest
code: plot_forest(   data,   score,   metric = "z",   test,   group,   ci.lb,   ci.ub,   axis.label.metric = metric,   descriptors = TRUE,   shading = TRUE,   abbreviations = FALSE )

title: Plot a Forest Plot — plot_forest
text: data data frame containing data plotted. score column name data frame representing scores plotted. metric metric scores data frame. Defaults "z". metric can converted "z". test column name data frame representing test names. group column name data frame representing group names. ci.lb (Optional) column name data frame representing lower bound confidence interval. ci.ub (Optional) column name data frame representing upper bound confidence interval. axis.label.metric metric used axis labels. Defaults value metric. Can "percentile", "t", "index", "scaled", "z". descriptors (Optional) Logical value indicating whether include descriptive labels plot. Defaults TRUE. shading (Optional) Logical value indicating whether include shading plot average range. Defaults TRUE. abbreviations (Optional) Logical value indicating whether abbreviate test names. Defaults FALSE.

title: Plot a Forest Plot — plot_forest
text: ggplot object representing forest plot.

title: Plot a Forest Plot — plot_forest
code: # Example data frame df <- data.frame(   test = rep(c("Test1", "Test2", "Test3"), 2),   group = rep(c("Group1", "Group2"), each = 3),   score = c(1.2, 2.3, 1.5, -1.2, 0.5, 1.1),   ci.lb = c(0.8, 1.8, 1.2, -1.5, 0.2, 0.8),   ci.ub = c(1.6, 2.8, 1.8, -0.9, 0.8, 1.4) )  # Plot with default settings plot_forest(df, score = score, test = test, group = group, ci.lb = ci.lb, ci.ub = ci.ub)   # Plot with no descriptors and shading plot_forest(df, score = score, test = test, group = group, ci.lb = ci.lb, ci.ub = ci.ub, descriptors = FALSE, shading = FALSE)

title: Plot Stability — plot_reliable_change
text: Plot Stability

title: Plot Stability — plot_reliable_change
code: plot_reliable_change(   data,   metric = "z",   group,   test,   t1.score,   t2.expected,   t2.score,   t2.ci.lb,   t2.ci.ub,   axis.label.metric = metric,   abbreviations = TRUE )

title: Plot Stability — plot_reliable_change
text: data data frame containing input data. metric metric used ("z" default). group grouping variable data. test test variable data. t1.score score time point 1. t2.expected expected score time point 2. t2.score actual score time point 2. t2.ci.lb lower bound confidence interval time point 2. t2.ci.ub upper bound confidence interval time point 2. axis.label.metric metric used axis labeling (default "z"). abbreviations Logical, whether abbreviate test names (default TRUE).

title: Plot Stability — plot_reliable_change
text: ggplot object representing stability plot.

title: Custom ggplot2 theme — plot_theme

code: plot_theme()

title: Custom ggplot2 theme — plot_theme
code: library(ggplot2) ggplot(mpg, aes(displ, hwy)) +   geom_point() +   plot_theme()

what: Confidence intervals for the abnormality of a test score using a modified t-test. — prevalence_intervals_t

text: Confidence intervals abnormality test score using modified t-test.

title: Confidence intervals for the abnormality of a test score using a modified t-test. — prevalence_intervals_t
code: prevalence_intervals_t(c, n)

title: Confidence intervals for the abnormality of a test score using a modified t-test. — prevalence_intervals_t
text: c observation non-central t-distribution N − 1 d.f. n Size normative sample.

title: Confidence intervals for the abnormality of a test score using a modified t-test. — prevalence_intervals_t
text: list containing lower upper bounds 95% confidence interval abnormality test score.

title: Confidence intervals for the abnormality of a test score using a modified t-test. — prevalence_intervals_t

what: Calculate the percentage of the normative population with j or more abnormal test scores — prevalence_of_j_abnormal_scores
title: Calculate the percentage of the normative population with j or more abnormal test scores — prevalence_of_j_abnormal_scores
text: function calculates percentage normative population exhibit j abnormal test scores battery tests. method uses multivariate normal simulation.

title: Calculate the percentage of the normative population with j or more abnormal test scores — prevalence_of_j_abnormal_scores
code: prevalence_of_j_abnormal_scores(R, sims = 1e+05, threshold = -1.645)

title: Calculate the percentage of the normative population with j or more abnormal test scores — prevalence_of_j_abnormal_scores
text: R correlation matrix tests. sims Number simulations perform. Default 100000. threshold Threshold abnormal test scores. Default -1.645 (corresponding 5th percentile standard normal distribution).

title: Calculate the percentage of the normative population with j or more abnormal test scores — prevalence_of_j_abnormal_scores
text: list containing: props Proportion individuals j-1 abnormal scores. props.two.tail Proportion individuals j-1 abnormal scores, adjusted two-tailed test.

title: Calculate the percentage of the normative population with j or more abnormal test scores — prevalence_of_j_abnormal_scores
code: # Example usage with a 4x4 identity matrix as the correlation matrix R <- diag(4) prevalence_of_j_abnormal_scores(R) #> Abnormality of j abnormal scores in a battery of tests. #>  #> Parameters: #>  #> k:                         4 #> Number of simulations:     1e+05 #> Abnormality threshold: z = -1.645 #>  #> Output (One-Tailed): #>  #> Proportion of people with more than: #> 0 abnormal scores: 18.56% #> 1 abnormal scores: 1.38% #> 2 abnormal scores: 0.05% #> 3 abnormal scores: 0.00% #>  #> Output (Two-Tailed): #>  #> Proportion of people with more than: #> 0 abnormal scores: 37.13% #> 1 abnormal scores: 2.75% #> 2 abnormal scores: 0.10% #> 3 abnormal scores: 0.00%

what: Calculate reliable_change using various methods — reliable_change
title: Calculate reliable_change using various methods — reliable_change
text: function calculates reliable_change using different methods Crawford, Jacobson, Speer, others.

title: Calculate reliable_change using various methods — reliable_change
code: reliable_change(   method = "crawford",   t1.score,   norm.t1.mean,   norm.t1.sd,   norm.t2.mean,   norm.t2.sd,   norm.r,   norm.n,   conf.level = 0.9 )

title: Calculate reliable_change using various methods — reliable_change
text: method method used reliable_change calculation. Default "crawford". t1.score score time 1. norm.t1.mean Mean normative data time 1. norm.t1.sd Standard deviation normative data time 1. norm.t2.mean Mean normative data time 2. norm.t2.sd Standard deviation normative data time 2. norm.r Pearson correlation coefficient time 1 time 2 scores. norm.n Sample size normative data. conf.level Confidence level confidence interval calculation. Default 0.9.

title: Calculate reliable_change using various methods — reliable_change
text: list containing expected score time 2, standard error mean, lower upper bounds confidence interval.

title: Calculate reliable_change using various methods — reliable_change
code: reliable_change(method = "jacobson", 100, 103, 10, 109, 8, 0.76, 100, .95) #> Reliable Change: Assessing if there has been a statistically significant change over time between two scores. #>  #> INPUT: #>  #> Variable    Mean   SD  Case's Score   n     r     #> ---------  -----  ---  -------------  ----  ----- #> Time 1       103   10  100            100   0.76  #> Time 2       109    8                             #>  #> PARAMS: #>  #> Change method:    jacobson #> Confidence level: 0.95 #>  #> OUTPUT: #> Estimate for Time 2: 100 #> Standard error:      6.93 #> Confidence interval: 86.42 to 113.58

title: Compare Stability Methods — reliable_change_discreps
text: function compares stability methods given scores two tests.

title: Compare Stability Methods — reliable_change_discreps
text: t1.score Scores first test. t2.score Scores second test. norm.t1.mean Mean normative sample time 1. norm.t1.sd Standard deviation normative sample time 1. norm.t2.mean Mean normative sample time 2. norm.t2.sd Standard deviation normative sample time 2. norm.r Reliability normative sample. norm.n Sample size normative sample. conf.level Confidence level stability assessment. methods character vector specifying methods calculate. Default "" methods.

title: Compare Stability Methods — reliable_change_discreps
code: # Example data t1.score <- 88 norm.t1.mean <- 113 norm.t1.sd <- 7.2 norm.t2.mean <- 118.7 norm.t2.sd <- 8.3 norm.r <- 0.93 norm.n <- 821 t2.score <- 103 ci <- 0.95  # Using all methods result_all <- reliable_change_discreps(t1.score, t2.score, norm.t1.mean, norm.t1.sd, norm.t2.mean, norm.t2.sd, norm.r, norm.n, ci) print(result_all) #> Comparison of Stability Methods #>  #> INPUT: #>  #> Variable     Mean    SD   Case's Score  n     r     #> ---------  ------  ----  -------------  ----  ----- #> Time 1      113.0   7.2             88  821   0.93  #> Time 2      118.7   8.3            103              #>  #>  #> PARAMS: #> Confidence level: 95% #>  #> OUTPUT: #>  #> Method      Predicted   Observed   Discrepency   Error   CI lb    CI ub      Z #> ---------  ----------  ---------  ------------  ------  ------  -------  ----- #> jacobson        88.00        103         15.00    2.69   82.73    93.27   5.58 #> speer           95.45        103          7.55    2.69   90.18   100.72   2.81 #> chelune         93.70        103          9.30    2.69   88.43    98.97   3.46 #> mcsweeny        91.90        103         11.10    3.05   85.92    97.88   3.64 #> charter         95.45        103          7.55    3.05   89.47   101.43   2.48 #> CH              91.90        103         11.10    3.07   85.88    97.92   3.62 #> temkin          93.70        103          9.30    3.09   87.64    99.76   3.01 #> iverson         93.70        103          9.30    2.91   88.00    99.40   3.20 #> maassen         89.88        103         13.12    2.91   84.18    95.58   4.51 #> crawford        89.88        103         13.12    2.93   84.14    95.62   4.48  # Using selected methods result_selected <- reliable_change_discreps(t1.score, t2.score, norm.t1.mean, norm.t1.sd,norm.t2.mean, norm.t2.sd, norm.r, norm.n, ci, methods = c("crawford", "maassen")) print(result_selected) #> Comparison of Stability Methods #>  #> INPUT: #>  #> Variable     Mean    SD   Case's Score  n     r     #> ---------  ------  ----  -------------  ----  ----- #> Time 1      113.0   7.2             88  821   0.93  #> Time 2      118.7   8.3            103              #>  #>  #> PARAMS: #> Confidence level: 95% #>  #> OUTPUT: #>  #> Method      Predicted   Observed   Discrepency   Error   CI lb   CI ub      Z #> ---------  ----------  ---------  ------------  ------  ------  ------  ----- #> crawford        89.88        103         13.12    2.93   84.14   95.62   4.48 #> maassen         89.88        103         13.12    2.91   84.18   95.58   4.51

what: Standard Error of Difference Between Means — se_difference
title: Standard Error of Difference Between Means — se_difference
text: Calculate standard error difference (SED) means.

title: Standard Error of Difference Between Means — se_difference
code: se_difference(sd.1, sd.2, r)

title: Standard Error of Difference Between Means — se_difference
text: sd.1 (numeric) Standard deviation first group vector standard deviations observation first group. sd.2 (numeric) Standard deviation second group vector standard deviations observation second group. r (numeric) reliability test used obtain standard deviations.

title: Standard Error of Difference Between Means — se_difference
text: standard error difference means.

title: Standard Error of Difference Between Means — se_difference
text: SED expected spread distribution change scores actual change occurred. calculated using approach offered Iverson (2001) uses SEM normative data testing interval.

title: Standard Error of Difference Between Means — se_difference
code: # If sd.1 and sd.2 are single values se_difference(sd.1 = 3, sd.2 = 4, r = 0.5) #> [1] 3.535534  # If sd.1 and sd.2 are vectors of the same length se_difference(sd.1 = c(3, 4, 5), sd.2 = c(4, 5, 6), r = 0.5) #> [1] 1

code: se_mean(dat = NULL, sd = NULL, n = NULL)

title: Standard Error of the Mean — se_mean
text: dat (numeric) numeric vector calculate standard deviation sample size. provided, sd n ignored. sd (numeric) standard deviation data. Ignored dat provided. n (numeric) sample size. Ignored dat provided.

title: Standard Error of the Mean — se_mean
text: standard error mean.

title: Standard Error of the Mean — se_mean
code: # If dat is provided, calculate sd and n from dat se_mean(c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5)) #> [1] 0.7071068  # If sd and n are provided se_mean(sd = 3, n = 30) #> [1] 0.5477226  # If dat is not provided but sd and n are provided se_mean(sd = 3, n = 30) #> [1] 0.5477226

title: Standard Error of Measurement (SEM) — se_measurement

code: se_measurement(dat = NULL, sd = NULL, r = NULL)

title: Standard Error of Measurement (SEM) — se_measurement
text: dat (numeric) numeric vector measurements calculate standard deviation. Ignored r SD provided. sd (numeric) standard deviation measurements. dat provided, sd calculated dat. r (numeric) reliability test.

title: Standard Error of Measurement (SEM) — se_measurement
text: standard error measurement (SEM).

title: Standard Error of Measurement (SEM) — se_measurement
text: Standard Error Measurement standard deviation infinite number hypothetical scores around true score. SEM calculated standard deviation (SD) multiplied square root 1 minus test retest reliability (r) measurement tool.

title: Standard Error of Measurement (SEM) — se_measurement
code: # If dat and r are provided, calculate sd from dat and then SEM se_measurement(dat = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5), r = 0.4) #> [1] 1.224745  # If sd and r are provided, calculate SEM se_measurement(sd = 3, r = 0.4) #> [1] 2.32379

title: Standard Error for n1 — se_n1
text: sd.1 Standard deviation first variable. sd.2 Standard deviation second variable. r Reliability coefficient (reliability test). n Sample size. t1.score Score first test. t2.score Score second test. norm.t1.mean Mean norm group first test.

title: Standard Error for n1 — se_n1
text: standard error sample size n=1.

title: Standard Error for n1 — se_n1
code: # Example usage: se_n1(sd.1 = 3, sd.2 = 4, r = 0.8, n = 100, t1.score = 75, norm.t1.mean = 70) #> [1] 2.278221

what: Calculate confidence intervals and percentile ranks — sem_to_percentiles
title: Calculate confidence intervals and percentile ranks — sem_to_percentiles
text: function calculates confidence intervals test scores percentile ranks.

title: Calculate confidence intervals and percentile ranks — sem_to_percentiles
code: sem_to_percentiles(   x,   R = NULL,   sem,   dp = 2,   names = NULL,   conf.level = 0.9,   abnorm_level = 5,   threshold = -1.645,   abnormality = TRUE )

title: Calculate confidence intervals and percentile ranks — sem_to_percentiles
text: x numeric vector test scores. R correlation matrix test scores. sem numeric vector standard error measurement (SEM) values. dp Number decimal places rounding results. Default 2. names Optional character vector names test scores. provided, default names used. conf.level Confidence level confidence interval. Default 0.90. abnorm_level Threshold percentile classifying scores abnormally low. Default 5. threshold Z-score threshold classifying abnormal scores. Default -1.645. abnormality Logical, whether calculate abnormality statistics. Default TRUE.

title: Calculate confidence intervals and percentile ranks — sem_to_percentiles
text: list containing various statistics including: tests Names test scores. x Original test scores. ci.lb Lower bound confidence interval. ci.ub Upper bound confidence interval. rank Percentile rank test scores. rank.ci.lb Percentile rank lower bound confidence interval. rank.ci.ub Percentile rank upper bound confidence interval.

title: Calculate confidence intervals and percentile ranks — sem_to_percentiles
Sequential Bonferroni Correction — sequential_bonferroni
text: Applies Sequential Bonferroni correction vector p-values.

title: Sequential Bonferroni Correction — sequential_bonferroni
code: sequential_bonferroni(p.vals, alpha = 0.05)

title: Sequential Bonferroni Correction — sequential_bonferroni
text: p.vals numeric vector p-values adjusted. alpha numeric value representing significance level (default 0.05).

title: Sequential Bonferroni Correction — sequential_bonferroni
text: list following components: sig logical vector indicating p-values significant correction. adj.p.vals numeric vector adjusted p-values.

title: Sequential Bonferroni Correction — sequential_bonferroni
text: function applies Sequential Bonferroni correction control family-wise error rate (FWER) performing multiple hypothesis tests. adjusts significance threshold p-value based rank ordered list p-values.

title: Sequential Bonferroni Correction — sequential_bonferroni
code: # Example p-values p.vals <- c(0.001, 0.04, 0.003, 0.08)  # Apply the sequential Bonferroni correction results <- sequential_bonferroni(p.vals)  # Print significant results results$sig #> [1]  TRUE FALSE  TRUE FALSE  # Print adjusted p-values results$adj.p.vals #> [1] 0.004 0.080 0.009    NA
